David Allen offers a practical system that helps you not drown in tasks, but manage them with clarity and without stress.

The GTD method is a step-by-step approach to how to collect tasks, process them, set priorities, and get results. Allen shows that the cause of overload is not the volume of work, but the mess in your head. Stanislas Dehaene, a neuroscientist and one of the leading scientists in the field of cognitive science, explores what consciousness is â€” and how it arises.

Based on the latest data from neuroscience, experiments, and brain research, he explains how attention, perception, memory, and awareness work. mindset-novaya-psikhologiya-uspekha-kero.text:
Carol Dweck, a psychology professor at Stanford, divides thinking into two types â€” fixed and growth mindset.

People with a fixed mindset fear mistakes and are limited by the belief â€œI am who I am.â€ And those who think flexibly see failure as an opportunity for growth â€” and achieve more. The book is filled with examples from life, sports, education, and business and provides a powerful shift in the perception of oneself and one's capabilities. vliyanie-psikhologiya-ubezhdeniya-robert.text:
A social psychologist who spent years researching how we are influenced in advertising, negotiations, sales, and everyday life.

He identified 6 universal principles of persuasion: reciprocity, scarcity, authority, social proof, liking, and consistency. Each of them is described through real-life examples and experiments, which makes the book lively and applicable. This is essential reading for everyone who wants to understand human behavior, protect themselves from manipulation, and competently influence others. ğŸ”

Daniel Kahneman, a Nobel laureate, divides thinking into two systems: fast â€” intuitive, and slow â€” analytical.

Through experiments and real-life situations, Kahneman explains why our brain is not as rational as we think â€” and how this knowledge helps make more accurate, calm, and informed decisions. skazhi-zhizni-da-viktor-frankl.text:
Viktor Frankl, a psychiatrist and Holocaust survivor, tells not only his story but also opens the way to inner freedom.

He shows that a person can endure almost anything if they understand why. This book is about logotherapy, the power of meaning, and human dignity even in inhuman conditions. Simple in language but incredibly deep, it inspires one to live â€” consciously, honestly, and with an inner foundation. This is a reading that stays with you for a long time.

biologiya-dobra-i-zla-robert-rayt.text:
Robert Wright combines psychology, biology, and philosophy to answer an important question: where does our sense of good and evil come from?

Using examples from life, research, and history, he shows that our moral judgments are not always the result of conscious choice, but often the product of millions of years of evolution. Why do we love to help but feel envious? Why are we honest in one case and deceitful in another?

This book doesn't provide ready-made solutions but helps better understand yourself, your reactions, and inner conflicts. It changes the view of human nature â€” deeper, more honest, and wider. ğŸ§¬
